name: Kepler-344
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-344 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-344 is a star with 0.9169999999999999 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.98 times its radius. It is located 3366.19 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-344 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-344 b

Kepler-344 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.15 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 21.96 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-344.

The mass of Kepler-344 b is 9.63 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-344 b is 2.61 that of Earth. At 9.63 Earth masses, Kepler-344 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-344 c

Kepler-344 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.49 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 125.60 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-344.

The mass of Kepler-344 c is 12.88 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-344 c is 2.95 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-344 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-344, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
